text:
This recipe was fantastic!  Everyone in my family loved it.  I was a bit concerned because this was my very first time using a slow cooker, and the directions say "cook on low for 4 hours", whereas in my crockpot (Rival 6 qt oval time programmable) the 4 hour option is in the "high" temp.  It wasn't a problem at all.  4 hours was the perfect amount of time for my 2.69 lb pork loin.  I followed the instructions to the letter because the ingredients seemed perfect---and they were.  For the wine, I used the wine I was drinking that night---a cabernet sauvignon.  Also, halfway through the cooking time I did stab the pork a couple of times so that the sauce would seep in.  I served this with some mashed potatoes (perfect side dish because there was plenty of sauce left over). I did thicken the sauce a bit after the pork was cooked and had been taken out of the slow cooker.  I used 2 tbsp of cornstarch and enough water to dissolve it and remove any lumps.  I poured this into the crockpot and stirred for a minute and let it sit in a high temp for 10 min.  It was great---a definite keeper!

text:
I wish I could give this 6 stars.  My husband made obscene noises when he tasted it and my daughter who is sick and has no appetite even ate a large helping.  Here is what I did - we are not big garlic people, so I made a dry rub of salt, pepper, onion powder and garlic powder and rubbed the tenderloin down.  Then I seared it in a pan before putting it in the crockpot.  The rest of the ingredients, I mixed them all in a bowl (used the liquid to deglaze the pan I seared in for the heck of it), and poured that over the pork.  When it was done (cooked it for 6 hours on low), I poured the juices in a saucepan, brought them to a boil, and added flour and water to make gravy.  Amazing is right!

text:
Good, simple recipe which turned out excellent with a few additions.
My only major change was in replacing the dry onion soup with a fresh onion, cut in rings.To the cup of water, I added a tsp. of beef stock. My choice of wine was what I had... a Chianti. Other than that, it came down to adding a bit more flavor. I added rosemary, thyme, celery powder, a splash of worcestershire, granulated garlic and parsley. Cook time was right on, and the Tenderloin was "melt in your mouth." Strained the onion into the au jus to thicken the gravy slightly, (which was delish,) and served with mashed potatoes. Thanks for the post, LLAU.

text:
WOW!  This is the best thing I've ever made in the crock pot!  I almost always make a recipe exactly as it states the first time, and then make my modifications.  After reading a couple of reviews that complained about it being bland, I decided that I was going to put slivers of garlic in the roast before cooking it.  I LOVE garlic, and ended up using half a head (yeah, that's not a typo) throughout the roast.  If you've never done it before, all you do is stab the roast and shove a clove or half a clove in the slit.  This way the flavor permeates the meat.  Anyway, I used LOW SODIUM soy sauce and everything else as stated.  It was done and super tender after the four hours, but I cooked it on low for about another half hour then kept it on warm until my husband came home.  I decided to add a little corn starch to thicken the juices, and man, was this roast incredible!  I could cut the meat with my fork!  Everyone should absolutely try this once!

Quite a few said that this recipe was too salty.  I make my own dry onion soup mix (equals 1 packet) -- 8 tsp. dried onion flakes, 1 1/2 tsp. dried parsley, 1 tsp. onion powder, 1 tsp. tumeric, 1/2 tsp. celery seed, 1/2 tsp. sugar, and 1/4 tsp. ground pepper.  Hope this helps.

text:
At the risk of sounding like a know it all I should like to pass along a few hints about salt content on this recipe. Dry onion soup is high in salt and also  contains MSG another salt/flavour enhancer. Better to use either a sliced fresh onion  or 1T of dehydrated onions and a cup of low sodium beef broth. Soy sauce is another source of high sodium; the alternative is low salt soy sauce. For a crust, roll the tenderloin in salt free crackers and potato flakes mixed with herbs de provence (basil,parsley,marjoram,chevril and oregano) or herbs of your choice. For those who want that extra kick of salt add it to your own serving at the table.

text:
Ended up making this with a 5-pound pork butt for a New Year's Eve dinner party.  I'm usually not a red wine drinker but knew that some of my guests were, so I decided to try and find a recipe that I already had all the ingredients on hand for and this one certainly fit the bill.   Oh boy, was this good!!! I followed the directions for the most part, but studded the meat with garlic slivers and used my best Merlot as per other reviews.  Cooked it on low for 7-8 hours, pulled it out, the meat literally fell off the bone, piled the chunks on a pretty platter, covered it loosely with tin foil while I thickened the sauce with cornstarch on high for a few minutes and then poured a little over au jus style, leaving the rest for my guests to use over potatoes.  As a side dish, I sauteed a mixture of sugar snap peas, baby pearl onions and roasted red pepper strips seasoned with garlic salt and a little red pepper.  Added our favorite cheese bread from the deli and ended up with an extremely easy to fix meal that all 10 of our guests raved about.  And me, the white wine drinker, can't wait to dig into the leftovers tonight!

text:
Sure this may have been fav'd by lots of home cooks, but that is more representative of how many people will put the WRONG cut of meat in a slow cooker. The flavor profile looks fine, just DON'T use tenderloin. Instead go choose a cheaper shoulder or leg cut for this and the flavor will be even better. Save tenderloin for grilling or quick roasting where you can even leave it slightly under done, like med-well. It will be very tender, and you get to taste a high quality cut the way it's meant to be served.

Really good, took one star off for presentation.  These slow cooker dishes that aren't seared first never look very pretty.  I wouldn't plan to serve this to company unless you sear first.  This was really easy and a great thing to make when you don't have a lot of time but want something a little special.  My tenderloin was one of those grocery store 2-packs, total weight was 1.7 lb. I strained the juice into a saucepan and thickened with a little cornstarch to make a really tasty gravy.  I bet this would work fine with a cheaper cut of meat if you don't want to waste such a tender cut in the slow cooker.

text:
OMG this was SO delicious & my husband could not stop smacking & licking his lips....
HOWEVER... it was too salty.(i even added 1 chopped peeled raw potato to the pot to try to de-salt it.)
so next time, i'll add a couple of quick splashes of soy sauce (& i used low sodium by the way) rather than the recipe amount AND i will NOT salt the loin prior to cooking (HUGE mistake..) the stock & soysauce & onion soup mix ALL have salt.. so please do NOT salt the meat..
so this is what i did;
i rubbed my 3 lb loin w/ salt , pepper, dried basil, celery seed/seasoning (not celery salt) & dried parsley.
then i seared it quickly on all sides.
then i placed it in the crock pot & added the stock, wine, soy sauce & onion rings on top of the meat & i pocketed raw garlic in slits on top..
high for 4.5 - 5 hrs.
then i strained the liquid & added 2 full tbsp of starch & let that boil on the stove . & that made the MOST DELICIOUS gravy we have both EVER had in our lives.
i served this w/ mashed potatoes (TIP: if you plan on mashed taters, do NOT salt the boiling water or the mashers themselves.. the gravy will be heavenly on a bed of soft plain ((well w/butter of course)) mashers.. i can NOT stress this enough).
this dinner was just jaw dropping.
trust me.
i will forever use this recipe
THANK YOU SO MUCH recipe poster :)

text:
We enoyed this recipe as it was. I took half the sauce from the slow cooker, added a little flour and made gravy. I served Jasmine rice and gravy along with the tenderloin. As a winemaker, I would like to comment that you should never substitute cooking wine for wine. They are very different and cooking wine has a really high percentage of salt (I have no idea why). I never ever use cooking wine. You should cook with the wine you plan to have with your dinner (unless, you're planning a very special wine for dinner). A day or so later, I took the leftovers (about 1/2 lb), cut the slices in half, and stuck them in the skillet with about 8oz sliced mushrooms, the gravy, and the rest of the sauce from the slow cooker. We put this over the leftover rice and, along with a salad, it was a great, fast dinner!

text:
Took the suggestion of the Start a Tradition: Slow Cooker Sunday article and made this recipe today for Sunday dinner (lunch according to my oldest daugher).  Okay, so it drives me crazy when someone reviews a recipe and has made so many changes and substitutions to the recipe, that they haven't made anything close to the original recipe - but here's what I did: Fixed a 3.19lb pork loin I had in the freezer. After rinsing the pork loin, I made slits and inserted 1/2 cloves of garlic about every inch or so, as suggested by another reviewer.  I omitted the wine and used beef broth instead.  Also, I wasn't sure about the taste of the soy sauce in this recipe, so I used worcestershire sauce.  The house smelled fabulous when we returned from church!  I did cook it on high for about 4.5 – 5 hours.  The meat was terrifically moist and fell apart as I was cutting it.  Using cornstarch/water, turned the juices into gravy.  It was little on the salty side, but not sure if that was due to the substitutions I made.  Overall, it was a great recipe and I definitely will be coming back to it again!!

text:
I read MOST of the more recent reviews before I made this today but when i put the two 1#  tenderloins in the slow cooker I followed the recipe exactly. I had heard too many people rave about the flavors and the amount of juices for gravy to not give it a try. It is aptly named Amazing and I concur. I will say that i'm aware of the new Dept of Agriculture guidelines for cooking pork to a temp of 145º  so after 2 1/2 hours i used an instant read meat thermometer and my meat was DONE. I turned off the slow cooker and kept all in the juices for another hour, took out the meat and made a little thicker gravy with flour/water added to the juices in a saucepan, returning the meat to the slow cooker to just stay warm. BIG HIT with my family when i served it over rice. I would guess that those who thought it was too dry or not cooked enough have issues with their slow cooker. Best tip I can give you? invest in a meat thermometer and you will not be disappointed with under cooked or over cooked meat. Definitely a keeper!

Excellent recipe, however I modified a few things that really worked well.  Rather than coating the roast in pepper after it's in in the pot, I coated it in fresh ground pepper and sea salt(pressed in the meat) and pan seared it in olive oil.   For the soup mix I specifically used Knorr French Onion, which has the best flavor in my opinion.  I quartered 2 yellow onions and added them to the mix. I made some additions based on the comments.  I made a rub of minced onion, garlic powder, salt, and pepper and rubbed that on the pork loin before searing it.   After searing, I deglazed the pan with the pinot noir I was using in the rest of the recipe. I put about half of a sliced onion in the bottom of the crock pot and put the roast on top of it. text:
This past weekend was the second time I made this terrific recipe but there are definitely minor modifications you should make.

The first time I made this, my loin was about 2.5 pounds and I set it on low for four hours.  Pork is cooked at 145 degrees.  After four hours, the thermometer shot up to 175 in about two seconds.  I don’t know what kind of slow cooker the original poster used…maybe it was old or weak.

This time the loin was three pounds.  I set it for THREE hours and at the 3-hour mark the temperature shot up to 150 degrees.  

So do NOT cook this for more than three hours and if you only use a 2-lb loin, I’d go way less than that.

Also, as many have said, this recipe is very salty.  I didn’t change any of the liquid quantities for the 3-lb loin and there was still MORE than enough delicious au jus.  I did use a little less than the whole onion soup packet (to cut the salt) and just added extra onion powder.  With the bigger loin and everything else the same (oh and I only use low-sodium soy sauce), no one complained that it was too salty this time.  It was REALLY delicious.

It goes VERY well with roasted string beans (roasted with a bit of olive oil, a thinly-sliced red bell pepper, crushed red pepper and the kicker, the zest of an orange), and some boxed pine nut couscous.

Definitely a go-to recipe for company because it’s so good and SO easy.

This was amazing.  I made it for a staff lunch and there were 4 plates practically licked clean and people begging me for the recipe.  I think I even got some brownie points with my boss!    Anyway, I did make a few modifications.  I used white wine instead of red.  I had used red another time I made this and the white tastes much better to me in this recipe.  Also, the entire envelope of onion soup mix made the au jus too salty last time so I used only about a TB of it.  Closed the envelope back up and will save the rest for other times I make this again.  I used less garlic as well - probably about 1 TB.  It was plenty.  Used lots of peppercorn.    Otherwise followed the recipe and it was very very good and extremely tender. I served it with mashed potatoes and folks poured the au jus over the potatoes as well.

text:
The name really suits this-it is amazing!Amazingly easy and delicious! When I found this recipe, I knew it was a great base to start with...and after reading many reviews I decided to make some additions and substitions. First, I seasoned the loin with pepper, onion powder, garlic powder,bay, rosemary and thyme. Then I seared it on all sides before putting it in the crock pot with 3/4 cup Malbec, 1/2 c. h2o, 1/2 c. reduced sodium chicken stock, 1/2 of a package onion soup mix, 1/2 sliced onion, 2tbls. soy sauce, and more of the herbs that I seasoned the pork with. I cooked it on low for 5 hours...the pork shredded beautifully, and I drained the juices from the crock pot into a sauce pan, brought to a boil and added 1 tbls. cornstarch and made a delicious gravy...served with steamed broccoli and mashed baby red potatoes...this earned raves from my hubby and even my 2 year old (who never eats, I swear she is going to waste away to nothing) ate it up happily!!! Will DEFINATELY make this again!! Thanks llau!!

text:
Just finished dinner and thought I'd get the family's impressions down right away. Over all it's a good recipe. It went together very quickly I have never had a pork tenderloin cook up as tender as this one did. Because so many reviewers warned about it being too salty I cut the soy sauce to 2T, and it was borderline salty. I cooked it for 6 hours on high because my crock pot although it's a fancy digital thing it doesn't have a choice of settings and 6 hours because I wasn't going to be around until then to deal with it. The meat was so tender that it fell apart. So I went ahead and pulled it apart, put the meat into an ovenproof dish, then I thickened the sauce with some cornflour and poured it all over the top of the meat. I had already started to make tiny new potatoes but at this point it looked so much like a "comfort" food, I pulled out the instant mash potatoes (I know, but the kids love them!) and did a big bowl up in the microwave. The kids made swimming pools in the potatoes and filled them up with the meat & gravy mixture and everybody was happy. Next time I might add some carrots and mushrooms. I'll make it again.

text:
I was looking for a recipe for pork loin, which I had never made before. I assumed pork tenderloin was the same, but it is not. My guess is pork loin would be the better meat to use for the crock pot as a tenderloin is smaller and, well, tender. Tenderloin can be seared on high heat in a short time. The five pound loin I bought could not. 
I wasn't sure how to adjust this recipe for my 5.5 pound boneless loin. After four hours on low I checked the temperature because I was so afraid it would dry out. It was done. However, it was not falling apart done. I left it on warm a few more hours, sliced it thin and served it in the sauce. 
Btw, although the meat portion was tripled, I only doubled the sauce. There was plenty because of the juices from the pork. I used a Cabernet Sauvignon. Next time I will use fresh onion instead of the soup packets. 
I planned on using the bits of leftovers for a quick supper over baked potatoes, but there were no leftovers.

I was hesitant about this one, because I don’t think pork tenderloin needs to be cooked in a slow cooker.  It is already a very tender cut of meat and doesn’t need to be cooked “low and slow” to become tender.  This recipe would be better suited to a pork loin roast, but I needed the ease of using my slow cooker, so I forged ahead. This was ok and Hubs ate it without complaint, but I won’t be making it again.

I suppose that this recipe does not need one more positive review, but I wanted to thank Chowsito for sharing this great dish with all of us. We are big fans of pork tenderloin, but I find that it often dries out in the crockpot. That's obviously because I have been cooking it for way too long. I couldn't believe that only four hours would suffice, but it does. The meat sliced beautifully, and stayed tender and juicy. I did sear it first, and added some fresh mushrooms that I also sauteed, then deglazed the pan with the wine. Served over noodles. It was just perfect, and I will use this recipe often.

text:
This is a wonderful, simple recipe.  I used a boxed Shiraz/Cab blend that I had in a box on the counter.  I could only squeeze 1/2 cup from the bag before it was empty, but it provided wonderful flavor.  Like another reviewer, I studded the loin with about 9 cloves or chunks of garlic (in lieu of rubbing pressed garlic on the meat surface), which I removed at the end of cook time before cutting the meat.  It added good flavor.  After removing the meat, I poured the juices into a sauce pan, simmered them, and stirred in some cornstarch (which I had spooned into a small dish and mixed with some water first to avoid lumps).  This quickly thickened the sauce to a lovely brown gravy, which we served over homestyle mashed potatoes (skins on, sour cream and butter mixed in while mashing).  My husband and kids LOVED it!  Next time, I am going to use low-sodium soy sauce, and consider taking it back to 2 T, because the saltiness was just on the edge of being too much.  Also, I have to admit that my meat was a bit tough and dry (the gravy smothered it oh so nicely, so it was fairly easy to ignore), but I think that has more to do with the cut of meat, or the amount of time I left it in (7ish hours on low), than a problem with the recipe.  Thanks for the great recipe!

I slightly modified this recipe according to some suggestions: I added slivers of garlic in the tenderloin before cooking it (by making holes in the tenderloin with a knife and putting slices of garlic in the slits). I also used 1/2 of what the recipe calls for of LOW SODIUM soy sauce and replaced the other half with worcestershire sauce. And I used 1 cup of cooking red wine (instead of 3/4 cup). Everything else as stated. I cooked it on low for four hours. I cut the meat and cooked it for an additional 30 minutes. I served it with the Tasty Green Beans and the Easy Mushroom Rice recipes which were a great compliment. AWESOME MEAL!

text:
Outstanding.. gets a five for ease and flavor.  I took the advice from several reviews and used only a third of the soy sauce and two thirds worcheshire sauce.  After about 4 hours and the meat fell apart so nicely, I took the liquid, added some water - enough for the amount of gravy I wanted and brought that to a boil.  I mixed up some cornstarch and milk(can be water but I like creamier gravy) and poured it into the boiling drippings.  Makes an incredible tasting gravy for potatoes, rice or noodles, and over the meat.  My significant other told me dinner was very good 4 times before he left that night.

This recipe has a major flaw ... cooking time/temperature. 
After 4 hours at low, I tested the temperature ... only 105 degrees. That is far too low for pork. 
Perhaps 4 hours at high ... perhaps 1 hour at high and then 3-4 hours at low might work. In any case 4 hours at low is inadequate from a food safety point of view.

Incredibly tasty and very easy to make.  Cook it for the suggested time and you have a tender pork loin that tastes great.  I did find different ways the more I used the recipe.  Once, it worked out that it cooked longer than the suggested time (5.5 hours) I found that the meat simply broke down and became a lovely "pulled pork" dish. For leftovers, I simply threw the "pulled pork" into a pan with some spicy BBQ sauce, caramelized it a bit, then served it on fresh hoagie rolls.  Yum!!!

text:
FANTASTIC! I used a pork loin roast (did not sear) and did change up a few things.
-I swapped the wine for 1/2 cup of Wild Turkey Bourbon 101 
-used fresh sliced onions in addition to the onion soup mix
-used almost a whole bulb of garlic, minced by food processor
-added thyme
-added sliced (canned) mushrooms towards the last 30 mins of cooking (4 hours on high)
-thickened the final sauce with a heaping tablespoon of cornstarch in 1/4 cup water

I have cooked this cut of meat before, using different methods, and have never been as pleased as I was today. The flavor had an aromatic sweetness to it, the meat was soft and tender, and it was easy to throw together. Served with rice & broccoli and my 19 month old son gobbled it up just as enthusiastically as his mom and dad did. :-)

text:
Great recipe! However, some changes are needed. I, too, found the tenderloin to be a bit too salty even though I replaced the regular with the reduced sodium soy sauce. Also, I used a 2011 Cabernet Sauvignon (never cook with something that you wouldn't drink, and cooking wines are just plain heinous), 2 frozen garlic cloves, and added a pack of fresh cremini mushrooms, two small pinches of rubbed sage and thyme, 3 lbs. of tenderloin along with the rest of the listed ingredients in a 5 qt. cooker on low for six hours. The house smelled amazing, and the juices were extemely flavorful. Also, I placed the meat on a dish to rest. Strained the liquid and placed it in a pot and added some cornstarch along with H20. I served the meat and gravy with mashed potatoes and grilled asparagus.

Again, it was a tad bit salty for my taste even with the substition (I added a little sugar to the gravy about 2-3 pinches to help mash the salty taste). Next time I'll cut the reduced sodium soy sauce in half and maybe add worcestershire sauce.

text:
I have never written a review although I cook from this site all the time. Like another reviewer I had my doubts using pork tenderloin in a slow cooker as well, but I followed the recipe which I usually don't do either. I did add a lot of garlic cloves in slits in the pork, lined the bottom of the pan with sliced onions I had on hand, and covered the pork with jarred chopped garlic (we like a LOT of garlic). Cooked on high for 4-5 hours (was slightly frozen when I started)and basted with the wine sauce 4-5 times. When I went to go take it out of the crockpot, it fell completely apart. So what I ended up with was the best and leanest pulled pork you have ever had- on a toasted roll and some of the au jus- awesome. Not what I started out expecting, but really good just the same.

My boyfriend made this, and it was great! I never would have thought about it.  I can see how it could be too salty for some....the soy sauce plus Lipton Soup mix is a salty combo.  If salt is a problem, I would suggest using half the Soup Mix envelope and Low Sodium soy. I wouldn't skip the soy because it gives it that extra little something.  If anything add some more water?  I can see this being waaaay to salty if you were try try to use the sauce as a gravy.  Just a few spoonfuls over the meat on a plate is all you need. Less is more!!

text:
cooking a true pork tenderloin in liquid over 4 hours is oing to yield a tender meat. This recipe has good bones but I did not enjoy the end result. My loin was two pieces weighing just above 2lbs. I followed the directions as described. My ending result was a tender meat. The fat and other pieces floating were grey rown all over the meat. It was not an attractive presebtation, yes I wiped it off but it wasn't a "pretty" result. Taste was why I will not make this again. It tasted like red wine with a garlic kick. I think this recipe would be better with a red meat roast because the meat itself has strong flavor vs. Pork and would be partnered well rather than overwhelmed. My three kids and I all give it a thumbs down.

Other than that, it came down to adding a bit more flavor. I added rosemary, thyme, celery powder, a splash of worcestershire, granulated garlic and parsley. text:
I'm sorry to say I didn't like this.  I had high hopes and followed the recipe precisely, despite the fact that I usually take some liberties to adjust to our taste.  This seemed like something we would be ok with.  Nope!  

The texture of the meat was amazing - very moist and falling off the fork. Absolutely perfect!  However, I can accomplish this by cooking pork in any kind of liquid for hours in the slow cooker.

I actually let it sit on low for about 8 hours in the slow cooker (had to work and no timer on my pot) and it was at 160 degrees when I got home - the temp the package said the tenderloin would be perfect at.  I was a bit worried at first that it would be overdone but it worked out wonderfully.

The sauce though - not a big fan at all.  It was overly salty and very, very garlicy.  I think the soy sauce overpowered the wine immensely and didn't go well with the pork flavor at all.  Neither myself or my boyfriend found the smell appetizing and we both agreed that it was almost as if this dish couldn't quite figure out what flavor it should embrace.  I also think a whole packet of onion soup was way too much.

I don't think I'll be making this again.  It was an unfortunate bust for us.  If I could've saved the meat without the flavor I would've been happy but as it was, I just threw it out as there was no hope for seconds, let alone leftovers.

text:
Wonderful flavour. I did have a few problems however. I cooked it the night before intending to reheat the next night, but after the 4 hours, the meat (2 1-lb tenderloins) was tough. (I've never had a tough tenderloin before!) So, since the longer you cook the tenderer it gets, I salvaged the situation by adding enough water to almost cover the tenderloins and left it on low for an additional 6 hours overnight. (Mine is a new, 6-quart slow cooker with a hotter low setting than I'm used to, but I'm unsure whether this contributed to the toughness.) The additional cooking definitely made it tender. I also substituted apple juice for the wine as other reviewers did since I never have wine on hand, but left all other ingredients as specified and the flavour was fantastic. Will definitely make again, but will increase liquid and will not hesitate to leave it to cook all day. A+++!!

text:
My wife complains that I sometimes spend too much time in the kitchen cooking when guests arrive.  I decided to try this slow cooker recipe to reduce the active kitchen time.  Well, much less time away from guests and absolutely excellent results.  Guests raved about it.  Adjusted ingredients to accompany 3 lbs pork tenderloin to serve 8.  To reduce salt, followed advice of other reviewers.  Made my own onion soup mix substitute.  (10 oz frozen diced onions, 1 1/2 t dried parsley, 1 t onion powder, 1 t turmeric, 1/2 t celery seed, 1/2 t sugar).  Also replaced 1/2 of the soy sauce with Worcestershire.  The result was not at all salty but no one added salt at the table.  Several had second helpings and there were no leftovers.  Strained the juices to have a simple and easy flavorful gravy.  The quantity was more than adequate.  Will definitely make this again.

This is a wonderful and easy recipe for the crockpot.  My family enjoyed it.  For those who have had problems and issues with the cooking time, this recipe is for a "TENDERLOIN' pork roast.  I believe most of the problems result from people using a "PORK LOIN".  This is a completely different cut of meat and will not cook as quickly as the tenderloin.  Be sure what you are buying.  If you use the tenderloin it will cook in about 4 hours.

I  make  this  often.  The  flavor is  good,  but then, we  love  garlic. I would  reccommend for those  who don't, to  cut  back to  1 1/2 Tb. I  also added  my Simon and  Garfunkle spice  mix. Rosemary, and  Thyme) That  adds the  extra  flavor  some people  crave in pork. Overall, this  is  a wonderful  basic  Pork  loin  meal, We will have this  again.This  came  out  very  tender,  These days,  crockpots  vary in times, and  heat. For those  who had a dry roast,  maybe  it  was  cooked too long. I have 3 crockpots, and  have  learned to adjust  recipes  accordingly,  to  suit the recipe. If you wound  up with  a tough texture, but  it was  not  dry,  it  probably need  more  cooking time  in your  crockpot. If  it  came  out  dry, your  pot  probably cooks faster than the  one that  was  use  originally.

text:
I used two 1.5lb pork loins, which I rubbed with 1 teaspoon granulated garlic and 1/2 teaspoon black pepper (total, not each) and seared them with a teaspoon of olive oil before putting them in the crockpot; I did *not* add more pepper to the liquid since I'd already used it in the sear. I flipped the loins halfway through cooking and thickened the jus to a gravy consistency on the stove top, whisking in 1 tablespoon each corn starch and flour. I got 2 full cups of gravy after thickening, so it went a bit farther than the meat itself. It is fairly salty, so use a homemade onion soup mix and/or low sodium soy sauce if that is a concern; or just serve it over unsalted potatoes. 4 hours on low should be perfect for a 2lb loin (at least in my crockpot), but it was a bit too long for two 1.5lb loins.

text:
This was our dinner Saturday night. I had left it in the slow cooker whilst we went shopping. The pork tenderloin was one that had been in the freezer since the time when our local supermarket was selling them at a really low price.   l would have liked it better if I had used a low salt soy, but that would have been my only complaint. I served it with Colcannon. Colcannon is traditionally made in Ireland from mashed potatoes and kale (or cabbage), with scallions, butter, salt and pepper added. It can contain other ingredients such as milk, cream, leeks, onions and chives. There are many regional variations of this dish.It is often eaten with boiled ham or Irish bacon. At one time it was a cheap, year-round staple food,though nowadays it is usually eaten in autumn/winter, when kale comes into season, I cheated a bit of making this, I had prepared everything, (i only used potatoes, white cabbage and scallions as that was all i had to hand)  in advance, popped the potatoes etc into a microwave rice cooker pot (daft but it does work) and simply put the microwave on for 12 minutes whilst i put all the shopping away when we came back so the only job left to do was to mash the spuds and veg then serve the pork and colcannon which  was dribbled over with the au jus as suggested in the recepie.  Boy what a feed! Two happy campers went to bed happy, full and content.

I found this recipe cooked well but the salt content was way too much.  Remember the dry onion soup mix already has salt, soy sauce has salt. text:
I made this for dinner tonight and it was fantastic!  I've always grilled or roasted pork tenderloin and was looking for a different recipe.  I made a couple changes, partly due to what I had on hand.  I didn't have the onion soup mix so used a mushroom beef mix and added onion powder.  I substituted Worcestershire for the soy after reading another post and thought that sounded good.  The wine I used was a petit syrah which is a nice light red.  The tenderloin I had was only 1 lb.  I put it in my cooker on the Auto setting which starts high then goes down to low.  I checked it after 3 hours and it was already fork tender.  I left it in for another 20 min. or so while I got the rest of my dinner ready and it was perfect.  Served with jasmine rice and fresh green beans it was a super easy yet yummy dinner!  I will definitely make this again and will try adding some herbs like rosemary or sage.

text:
I went by some other reviews & substituted 1 T. dried onion flakes for the soup mix, & used low-sodium soy sauce to keep it from getting too salty.  Didn't have red wine so I risked it by using cooking sherry, but only 1/2 cup, then increased water amount to 1 1/4 cups.  It turned out to be spectacular.  The sherry gave it a nice subtle flavor, & it had just the right amount of salt flavoring.  I thickened the gravy from the crockpot by heating a small pan, melting 1-2 T. butter, then whisking in a few tablespoons of flour, & cooking for a minute.  Slowly added some of the gravy from crockpot to the pan until there was enough for the meal & thick enough for gravy consistency.  Cut pork into medallions & placed on rotini pasta. Poured gravy on top. Awesome!

Made this for the first time, so yummy and tender. I doubled the recipe exactly as directed and it came out perfect. Even my picky 5 year old ate it and my 7 year old told me to put it on the list. Even being doubled, we barely had enough for leftovers. text:
This was OK. To be fair, I'm giving 3 *, b/c honestly, I just don't think it deserves more than that (sorry!). My favorite tenderloin recipe on this site is Burgundy Pork Tenderloin (BROWNDOG). Yes, it requires more effort (slow cooking is the EASIEST way to prep. food - period!), but the end result is SOOOO worth it (IMHO). This had a very "odd" taste. I can't put my finger on it exactly tho... it could be the saltiness or maybe it's the combo. of soy/wine (???). My fiance liked this, but he too agrees that burgundy tenderloin is MUCH better. For those of you wanting to try this, I will say that the submitter's direct. are right on. Four hrs. on low is perfect. My 1 lb. tenderloin (all I could find were pkg. of 2, ea. 1 lb.) was fork tender (no knife needed). Other than using a sm. cut of meat, my only other ch. were rubbing a sm. amt. of herbs de Provence on both sides of my tenderloin & inserting several garlic slivers thruout, but I don't think either add. to the end prod. Even tho I "tech." 1/2'd this recipe, I did make the full amt. of gravy called for. I could not justify using 1/2 of an $$$ Lipton onion soup pk.! To make my gravy, I dumped all of the liquid from my sc into a sm. pot, add. 1 T cornstarch dissolved in 1 T H2O & brought to a boil to thicken. Served w/ mashed pottoes, green beans & Parm. knots (Cathy Adams), this was a nice meal on this cold, dreary fall day. Tx. for sharing, chowsito :)

text:
This recipe was no doubt, very good. My mother made it and I tried to recreate it. The problem was that I had 2.7 pounds rather than 2 and they were in two separate pieces of meat. I jacked up the amount of all the ingredients to account for the extra poundage. The problem is that I did not take into account that fact that they were two small pieces. It turned a bit too salty as well as a bit too garlicy(I followed the advice of putting slivers of garlic into the meat). It was definitely not too bland. I would recommend following the recipe exactly or  perhaps putting in a little less than the recipe calls for. Just be careful if you are sensitive to salt or garlic. Good recipe overall. The family liked it but also complained of an excess salt/garlic taste.

text:
Easy & delicious!   Even our 4-yr-old liked it.  I used two small pork loins (about 1 lb each) and browned them before adding them to the crock pot.  I used "Golden Onion Soup Mix" and added 2 tsp crushed dried rosemary and 1 large bay leaf to the crock pot during cooking.  I cooked the meat until it was falling apart tender (about 6 hours on med-low).  The pork was very tender and the sauce was a nice compliment to the meat and garlic mashed potatoes.  The sauce was a bit thin and probably would benefit from thickening as some others have recommended.

text:
Ugh. I don't like to give bad reviews & usually don't, but man oh man, I just had to say aomething about this pork. The meat itself turned out fall-apart tender, but c'mon... it's a tenderloin. The sauce however is another matter entirely. As a person who LOVES salt, salt, and more salt, I couldn't believe it when this sauce turned out to be so salty that I could hardly stand it. I think an entire package of onion soup mix is just way too much. If I ever attempted this dish again, I'd follow someone else's suggestion & replace the soup mix with fresh sliced onion. The salt could be had from the soy sauce or by using broth instead of water. I did only use half of the soy sauce along with 1 and a half TBSP of worchestershire, and I think that would've been good if it hadn't been so overpowered by the soup's salt.
I served this pork over white rice, but could only stand to use a little bit of the gravy. My husband and son skipped the gravy all together. Pity, because it was so darn pretty.

The title is perfect for this pork...amazing!!!  It smelled great and my husband gave it great reviews (and he is picky). text:
This was very good. I did follow some of the reviewers' tips and used what I had on hand. There's nothing wrong with cooking a pork tenderloin in a slow cooker. I wouldn't do it with a beef tenderloin but that's another story. I browned the loin first with some olive oil, salt and pepper. I also used a fresh onion, sliced. I had some French onion soup in a carton, so used that instead of the water and soup mix. I added rosemary, thyme, sage, cumin, and Worstershire sauce. I think the extra herbs helped. Four hours on low was probably enough but I let it go longer until we were ready to eat. I strained the juices and added cornstarch to make a gravy. It turned out great! And we have leftovers for open-faced hot pork-and-gravy sandwiches. Loved it!

text:
Dang! This was delicious. I used the written recipe as a guide and the previous reviews for inspiration. I started with a 4 pound pork roast (and I'm a single lady!) so I doubled all other ingredients. I substituted the water for beef broth and added one sliced onion, half of a minced ghost pepper, fresh thyme and fresh italian oregano. I made it nice and garlicky by shoving whole cloves in slices on the top of the meat. I left it in the crock pot on low for 8 hours and turned it up to high for the last 30 min. The meat fell apart beautifully. With the juices, I made an easy gravy using a heavy pour of whole milk, a heaping tablespoon of flour and nothing else. So freaking good. Seriously. Try it!

After all the talk about using a cheaper cut of meat than a tenderloin, I bought a 2# boneless Boston butt for this recipe, but had to trim alot of fat from it.  I used the low sodium homemade "Dry Onion Soup Mix" from this site, low sodium soy sauce and Merlot. I used the cup of water this time, but I don't think it needs that much liquid.  I'll try it with little or no water next time.  I cooked it on Low for 4 hours and it was exactly 145 degrees, perfect!  I thickened the juice with cornstarch and a little water to make gravy for the meat.  My SO is sick and really didn't like all the garlic but I loved it and didn't really detect a strong garlic taste.  Great recipe, thanks, chowsito, for submitting.  UPDATE:  I  used this recipe again to make a Smithfield fresh pork loin filet which is about the size of a tenderloin and almost as tender.   This time I went strictly by recipe. The sauce was great though quite salty and made a wonderful gravy but 4 hours on Low in the slow cooker is way too long.  Meat dried out as I'm sure a tenderloin would too.  Using tenderloin should only take 1 1/2 to 2 hours to be done at about 145°.

Comments like, "Wow," "This is great," and "Awesome," make this the best recipe for Pork Tenderloin I have used in a very long time.

Recommend a few variations that I used  to enhance this dish a bit.  Use a full cup of dry, rather than a fruity red wine, like a Merlot or Burgundy, which will add a very likeable and distinct essence to the pork.  I like garlic, so I added 4 tablespoons vice 3 of this essential, which when summed with the Onion Soup Mix, Soy Sauce and wine infuses the pork, with what you'll agree is "Nirvana."  Be sure and generously spoon the hot Nirvana Au Jus over the sliced pork when serving.

text:
Wow! This was so...Good! I change it up a little, because I was afraid it was going to be too salty as written. I used a 2 pound lean pork roast. I cut slits in the roast & add slices of garlic. Than seasoned the roast with 1/2 teaspoon of Thyme, 1/4 onions powder, & black pepper. I seared the meat in a pan first & cooked some fresh onions also. Than add to the slow cooker 2 Tablespoons of the dry onion soup mix, 1 cup of beef broth,a red sweet wine ( that's what I had on hand) & low sodium soy sauce. One hour before serving I add 2 TSP. of flour & 1/4 cup of water to thicken the sauce. Serve with brown rice. My husband couldn't stop talking about how much he loved this dish!

text:
After reading a lot of the reviews I decided to make this on Friday when company was coming over.  I usually have a rule against making new recipes when people are coming over, but the reviews were so good I thought I'd be safe.
The first thing I did differently was that I used a pork loin instead of a tenderloin. I couldn't make myself put a tenderloin in the slowcooker.  My loin was about 4.5 lbs so I put it in on low for about 5 hours. I also only put in 2 tablespoons of (reduced sodium) soy sauce, I only used 1/2 a cup of red wine (not cooking wine for fear that it would be too salty, I chose a cabernet sauvignon), I used reduced sodium beef broth instead of water.  I also added bay leaves and about a table spoon of worchestershire sauce. I took it out after about 5 hours on low, put the slow cooker on high, mixed a bit of flour and water together and added it to the sauce and stirred until there were no lumps.  The sauce thickened perfectly!  The pork was so tender it fell apart when I was taking it out, and then was almost impossible to cut properly.  My guests LOVED this!  I made it with rice and corn.  So delicious!  I am definitely going to make this again!!
Thanks for the recipe!

Made this recipe for New Year's Eve.  I worked that day, so had the dude put it together.  The night before I made the sauce, including the garlic, and placed it in a jar in the fridge.  I used a 6qt crockpot.  It has a thermometer, so we set the goal temp at 140 F and placed the crockpot on low.  We allowed 6 hours, since other reviewers had said it took longer.  The tenderloin had reached 140 F in about 2.5 hours, it sat on low until I got home.   Was very tender and moist.  The au jus was not too salty, maybe because I used Bragg's amino acids instead soy sauce.  I like 
 Gravy, so I thickened it up before serving.  I am saving the remaining juice/au jus to use in a future stew.

Pretty good taste and super tender. But like other reviewers, I am wondering why you would put a very tender cut of meat in a crockpot. A less expensive cut of pork (like pork butt) will give much more flavor and be better suited to slow cooking. Also, to cut down on the saltiness, use low-sodium soy sauce and low sodium onion soup mix. I used a good merlot for the wine, but also added some beef broth - very tasty. But next time I'm using a cheaper cut of meat and saving the pork tenderloin for the grill.

Small effort, huge payoff! This was so easy and came out so tender, delicious and flavorful. I took the tip from another reviewer and added 2 tbsp. of cornstarch dissolved in a little bit of water and added it to the liquid in the crock pot (after removing the cooked pork) and turned it on high for 10 minutes to thicken up. It made a delicious au jus that was fabulous on the simple smashed red potatoes that I had on the side. Add dinner rolls and salad and you'll impress all of your dinner guests!

I substituted 6 ounces of wheat beer for the red wine and added some freshly ground peppercorns into the batch. Turned out spectacular plus the peppercorns added a little kick to it. Family loved it. Plus after everything was done, look at what was left in the cooker, it is basically onion soup with some pork stock in it. I saved it and turned it into soup for next day's lunch. It was great.

text:
Okay, I'll confess.  I didn't make this exactly but the basic concept is great.  I was looking to do something different with my country style pork ribs that involved slow cooking in my oven and this turned out perfect.  Sliced a onion for the soup mix and I rubbed the ribs down with thyme, black pepper, some salt and garlic powder.  Skipped the fresh garlic because I didn't have time just then to chop it up.  I cooked it in a covered casserole dish at 300*F for 3 hours.  Drained the juices into a small pan.  Skimmed the grease off the top (remember I'm using country style ribs instead) and added a roux to thicken the stock for a gravy on the side.  YUM.

I Made this yesterday, I followed the recipe, except my tenderloin was 4.5lbs, and I added 1 cup of water to have more liquid. The house smelled amazing when I got home, the broth tasted great, and my pork was super tender, now the only problem that I had with this was the fact that the wine flavor was very strong in the meat, I didn't like that very much. Now the family loved it, or so they said, And I think it was pretty good, but really my personal opinion is these ingredients are better suited for a beef or lamb roast.

text:
With so many great reviews, I was excited to try this recipe, but should have heeded all the negative ones.  I followed the recipe exactly, but also studded the pork tenderloin with fresh garlic cloves. I also used Low Sodium soy sauce. After cooking it for 1 hour on High, and 3 hours on Low, the pork itself turned out moist and tender.  But the sauce was horrible.. so salty as to be inedible.  I rescued dinner by opening a can of Campbell's Beefy Mushroom soup, then adding a splash of Balsamic Vinegar, ground black pepper, and 1/4 cup of the juice from the slow cooker, and heating that up-- it made a great gravy.  The one in the cooker was just too horribly salty to eat as is.  I will make slow cooker pork tenderloin again, but not with the same ingredients--next time I'll try using the Campbells Beefy Mushroom plus some wine and fresh onions.  Thanks anyway.

Although I'm not typically a fan of pork, I thought this recipe was great - simple and tasty.  I did add a few sprinkles of some spices I saw suggested in comments, but not much. text:
This recipe was delicious. I love anything in a crockpot! I cooked 4.5 lbs of tenderloin, so was unsure about the cook time. I recalled 1 member saying that the meat was so tender is just fell apart, instead of slicing it. I cooked it for 5 hours on high and it still did that. I'm not complaining tho, because it was still delicious. I covered my pork tenderloin in a mixture of garlic powder, salt, pepper & onion powder. Then added the other ingredients. I used a pinot noir wine and it went nicely with the pork. I also added in a bit of sugar, because I found it to be a little too salty for our taste. At the end I thickened the sauce with cornstarch. We ate the gravy with the pork & over the mashed potatoes. I'll definitley make this again!

Instead of using a slow cooker(I researched and a lot of people said its a waste to slow cook since it is already a tender piece of meat and baking in the oven was better:)) I browned in a skillet on each side(ab 5 mins total) before baking in the oven for 15-20 minutes. This was absolutely amazing!!!  I cut back on the garlic just a little and added a bit more wine (about 1/4 a cup more) only because my pork loin weighed 2.5 lbs instead of the 2lb as stated.  This was filled with flavor and sooooo tender that it was falling off of the fork while I was cutting it.  I cooked it on low for 4 1/2 hours and high for the last 30 mins.  My children, ages 10 and 4, loved it!  Others said it was very salty, strong garlic flavor, bland and strong wine flavor but mine had none of that.  It was a perfect balance.  I will be making it again soon!

text:
OMG it is so yummy!  I was worried because of the mixed reviews, it seems like people either love it or hate it.  From what I can tell, if you hate the smell of it cooking, you will hate it.  I LOVED the smell, it drove me crazy!   I followed the recipe for the most part - 4 hrs on low is the correct timing, although I don't see how an hour more could hurt, but I wouldn't risk more than that.  The only differences I made were adding a dash of Worchestire sauce and I used a packet of pork gravy mix.  Also, I did not have any red wine on hand, so I used a white Zinfandel (Arbor Mist to be exact) instead.  I also poked a fork through the tenderloin about 4 times and about halfway through cooking I turned it over.   I served this with Stovetop chicken stuffing, and put some of the juice on top of it, and also made Hawaiian bread in the breadmaker - it takes 3 1/2 hours, so by the time the tenderloin was done, the bread was at the perfect temperature to eat! A fantastic recipe!

text:
This is a very good recipe.  I browned the meat first.  The only problem I have is that for pork tenderloin you really need to S L O W cook this meat. The  4 hours on LOW  stated here in the posted recipe  really isn't enough time for the tendons in the meat to break down. Ideally 8 to 10 hours on LOW is good for pork. When I don't have 8 hours, usually start the meat on HIGH for 2 hours then another 3-4 on LOW. The meat should be fork tender.

Followed the recipe exactly and took another poster's suggestion to add a corn starch/water mixture to the crock after removing the meat to thicken the gravy.  The meat was very tender & the gravy was the best part!

This recipe worked out very well. I've had poor luck with tenderloin in the past, but this one was a hit! I didn't have any red wine on hand, so I substituted 1/4 cup red wine vinegar, and 1 1/2 cups water, and used low-sodium soy sauce. Even my picky 6 year old son gobbled it up and asked for more! I cooked it on low for 4 hours, and then on high for another 1 1/2 hours, as it was not quite tender enough, but and the end, it was falling apart and I could cut it with a fork. THANKS!

Wow, I hardly eat meat, let alone pork and this recipe was awesome! The Au ju was very salty to serve as is, so I made a gravy. I started in a saucepan making a rue with butter and flour. Then added 3 or 4 laddles of the au ju and a couple of splashes of milk. Whisked and boiled it for 30 seconds and voila--gravy. To throw everything in the slow cooker took five minutes. Simple and tasty dinner!

text:
Very good recipe.  Here's what we did...

1.8lbs of tenderloin
some rosemary
sliced onions (not soup mix!)
2 cups of water (instead of one)
some beef broth
bit of soy sauce 
minced garlic.

gave the tenderloin a pan sear with olive oil, salt and pepper.  put it in the crockpot with all the other listed ingredients and let it go on high for probably 3.5 hours.  Not dry at all and it just fell apart.  

Our only complaint was that it is a bit salty, but since we used the liquid as an au jus, it was fine.  

we'll def. make this recipe again!

text:
I used a burgundy and the reader's tip to use 1/2 head of garlic. I found the meat tender but the overall taste was too salty from using the whole packet of dry onion soup and soy sauce quantities called for. With the reviewer's tip to insert 1/2 head of garlic, it was too overpowering for that delicately flavored meat. I think it would be good to do this with a nice red wine as the recipe calls for and perhaps 1/2 packet of onion soup mix. Doesn't need garlic beyond the minced garlic quantity called for to get a nice flavor w/o being overpowering. Tender roast, convenience of crock pot. Try adding mushrooms during last phase of cooking for another version of gravy.

text:
This recipe was absolutely wonderful!  Responding to the review from the 'experienced chef' who felt foolish after making this with a more expensive cut of meat.  I too am an experienced chef and have found that there are some wonderful slow cooker recipes out there.  This is one!  Pork tenderloin can easily be overcooked on a grill or in the oven and get dried out because it is so lean.  The outcome of my pork with this recipe was very tender and juicy.  Flavors were great and I loved the minced garlic on the top.  One change out of necessity - I didn't have dry onion soup mix but did have a can of Campbell's condensed french onion soup.  Used this with about 1/2 of the water called for in the recipe.  Otherwise made this as is with the exception of searing the meat on all sides before putting in the slow cooker; I ALWAYS do this.  Thanks for a great recipe that I will make again.  My husband loved it too!

text:
This is a keeper!! I used a pork loin (5 lb.) rather than a pork tenderloin. I seasoned it with garlic powder, onion powder, pepper and beau monde seasoning. Cut it in half and seared it on all sides in avocado oil. Took it out of the pan and let it rest for about 10 minuets. I followed the basic recipe except for the following... I used chicken stock instead of water, used 1/2 packet onion soup mix, added fresh diced onions and mushrooms, a little extra soy sauce and added some   worcestershire sauce, all to my tastes. Then I thought, why not? I added about 1/3 cup balsamic vinegar over the top. Added rosemary, thyme and sage and put the crock pot on high for 5.5 hours. Oh my goodness!!! The aroma in my house was fantastic! The pork was so tender and the flavor was to die for. I thickened the juice with cornstarch and water to make a gravy and ladled that over the sliced pork and served it with roasted baby red potatoes and asparagus. It just melts in your mouth. My husband said we should have this once a week lol! He loved it and I was amazed by the flavor.

text:
This was amazing!  I used a 2 lb pork loin roast, and when cutting it, the roast was so tender that it was just falling apart after 6 hours on low in the crock pot!  The sauce made a wonderful tasty au jus for the pork, and I still had plenty to take out and make gravy with after adding some milk and corn starch (which was heavenly over the mashed potatoes I made as a side).  My only issue is that this was pretty high in sodium, even when using regular wine (not cooking wine).  I normally never complain about dishes being too salty because I like my food to be flavorful, but this was such a sodium bomb that I had a headache after dinner!  I used Lipton Onion Soup Mix, but next time I make it, I'll use a lower sodium MSG-free alternative such as Simply Organic French Onion Dip Mix instead and possibly switch to Worcestershire sauce instead of soy.  But this recipe is a keeper for sure!

I have made this recipe several times with good reception each time. Based on other reviews complaining of high sodium, I used low sodium soy sauce. Additionally, I add celery powder, fresh rosemary, a dash of red pepper flakes, fresh onions, and Worcestershire. I also substitute the water with chicken broth (no sodium). My favorite wine to use is a merlot. Four hours on high has yielded good results for me. Finally, I always use a pork loin, since  pork tenderloin is a nicer cut of meat that does well in the oven.

text:
Lovely dish; the red wine really adds to the flavors.  I decided to follow some of the advice and used fresh slivered onions instead of the onion soup and also decreased the soy sauce initially.  I think that change was a bit too drastic and added more soy at the end.  With some recipes, there isn't enough au jus at the end, but this one I'd think would be adequate.  I had some pork that we had butchered, and so a 2lb bag ended up being less than a 1lb after I finished trimming the meat.  I kept the liquids amount the same and ended up with more than enough au jus to turn into gravy.  (3.5 hrs on low was adequate for the decreased amount of meat...maybe even 3 hrs).  Also, I added fresh rosemary at the beginning of the cooking time.  I read that woody herbs like rosemary, sage, and thyme hold up very well in the slow cooker.  We all liked the flavor that it imparted.  Thank you for a simple yet delicious dish!

We make this mostly as is (with the exception of using a pork loin rather than a tenderloin) and we love it.  I tried some of the variations in the reviews and like the original best.  Once I didn't have any wine on hand (shocker in my house) and used cooking wine instead.  It was SO salty we threw it out. Delicious! We followed the recipe exactly and the pork just fell apart. Served it with mashed potatoes and carrots, used the sauce from the slow cooker as a gravy. We're going to try it with rice next time. The meat on its own was flavorful. My fiance thought it was a bit too salty, so in the future we might use less soy sauce, but overall a great recipe that we will use in the future. Thanks! EDIT: Been a few months, we've made this numerous times, still sooo delicious! And wine to drink on the side! Definitely recommend using half the amount of soy sauce to reduce salty-ness. We serve the meat with a side of white rice, pouring the juices from the slow cooker over the meat/rice to soak up - best side dish we've tried so far. Sometimes add broccoli, too. My recommendations!

text:
This is my husband's FAVORITE! I have made it several times as written and also with modifications always comes out excellent  I like to add garlic slivers into the tenderloin (use almost an entire head of garlic).  I also use low sodium soy sauce or cut down a bit on the amount of soy sauce.  I always use dry red wine like a cabernet or chianti. I do add some corn starch at the end just to thicken the gravy a bit. Serve with mashed potatoes and green beans.

The other changes I make--our family preferences--I like to add "fresh" herbs like thyme and rosemary. I also at the end add sauteed mushrooms to the gravy.

Again, this is my husbands favorite recioe from this site!

My mom made this for New Year's Day 2015 and it was incredibly delicious. I just made this. The family really, really liked it. I mean really!My only changes were to flour, salt & pepper four 1+ lb. tenderloins and then brown them. I deglazed the pan and used 2 cans of beef broth, omitting the water. I used two packets of onion soup mix and also added 1 lb. of fresh mushrooms after lightly sautéing them to get out the excess water. I did stick with just 3/4 cup of wine. After cooking I removed the meat and added considerable flour while the slow cooker was on high. I thickened it to the most delicious gravy I've ever made. This is an absolute keeper! Thanks for posting!

I was really skeptical when I first saw that the recipe called for the meat to be cooked for only 4 hours on a LOW setting, especially since normally meat needs to be cooked for around 8 hours on low, but I decided to give it a try anyway. I can definitely confirm that 4 hours on LOW is completely fine.

I couldn't find any dry onion soup mix, so instead I used 1 brown onion, thinly sliced. The red wine I used was the cheapest I could find (the meal still turned out great so don't worry about using your most expensive bottles) and cost about 10 dollars.

With the juices from the cooking, I added a few gravy granules and made an incredibly rich gravy. Delicious!

text:
This turned out pretty well with a few modifications.  First off, I had to leave mine on low for twice the amount of time called for.  I was not able to slice my pork, as it literally fell apart upon being pierced.  It was not dry and was very very tender and flavorful.  The juice was a little strong tasting for my tastes so I added at least another cupo of water to dilute it before adding a thickener to make gravy.  This made the most awesome gravy!!  My family requested this recipe be put in the "keeper" file!  Thanks for sharing, chowsito!

text:
I made this recipe as written using Woodbridge Cabernet Sauvignon for my red wine. It was pretty good but the wine in the au jus was a little overpowering. I decided to separate and boil the au jus for a few minutes, then added 2 tsp of cornstarch blended with water to thicken it into a gravy. Still strong, until I added a sprinkle of sugar (yes sugar!) and some onion powder. Then the flavors seemed to blend perfectly. My husband and I loved this five star meal and served it with mashed potatoes and a broccoli vegetable medley. We will definitely make this again. Can't wait to eat the leftovers!

I just made this and WOW!!  The fiancé loved me tonight!

Changes... Cooked in oven at 350 for an hour.  Didn't have dry onion soup mix so used a "zesty herb" seasoning packet, red pepper powder, garlic, fresh pepper, soy sauce.  Towards the end, I added mushrooms to simmer in the sauce then took the pork loin out to chop up, put the sauce remaining on the stove, added more mushrooms and a mushroom gravy packet and served over mashed potatoes!

I will def make this for guests. Yum!

This was 100% EASY and VERY TASTY!  I did omit the soy sauce (first inadvertently, then just decided to skip it), because we're not big on salt/salty foods.  It won RAVE reviews from my family that joined us for dinner. I strained the sauce from the crockpot into a sauce pan, added 1/2 cup COLD water and 1/4 cup flour mixture to the sauce, boiled for about a minute to make a wonderful gravy to complement the pork.  Served it with Boursin mashed potatoes, spaghetti squash, and steamed brocolli ... Highly recommended the whole thing!

text:
This was so good and so flavorful.  I worried when I read through some of the reviews that it might be too salty; but I am SO glad I decided to try it.  I used a 2 lb "pork sirloin tip roast" from Costco, and instead of 3TBS soy sauce, I tried 2TBS soy sauce and 1TBS Worcestershire sauce.  I also probably only used 2TBS minced garlic (mainly sprinkling it on the top of the roast).  And for the wine I used was a Pinot Noir.  I cooked it in the slow cooker for 6hrs on high and it was moist and delicious!  I don't really recommend using the gravy though; because it is very salty.  But do try this---it's good--my picky kids ate it up as well; even asked for seconds!  Thanks for the yummy recipe.

text:
I made this recipe because it looked really easy and I am a busy Mom of 2 little girls. It was so easy to prepare, and actually cost me around $25 for the whole meal! (Including the wine!) We have a Hamilton Beach slow cooker so after 4 hours on low (like the recipe says) I checked it and the pork wasn't fully cooked. I cranked it up to high for 2 more hours and it was cooked perfectly! (Every couple of hours I dumped the juice/sauce over the tenderloin while it was cooking.) My husband and oldest daughter liked it, I liked it as well but when I make this next time I'm going to use less wine. I felt the wine was a little bit overpowering. (I used a $10 bottle of red Chianti so maybe that was why?) All in all it was an easy meal, that fed our family twice for around $25 which is something you can't beat!

Wow!  This was surprisingly good!  I did not have the Onion Soup Mix, but subbed a couple tablespoons of a product called Onion Onion. text:
I was looking for a new recipe for pork tenderloin and this was great. I studded the meat with small garlic cloves as other reviewers suggested and added a little minced garlic to the liquid as well (I really like garlic). I flipped the meat halfway through the cooking time (4 hours on high) since there wasn't enough liquid in the pot to cover the meat. I do think the cooking time could use a bit of tweaking since there seems to be some question on low vs. high heat but I'm not sure what the correct answer is; 4 hours on high was probably more time than it needed, but 4 hours on low may not have been enough. I added some cornstarch at the end to make the au jus into a gravy and served it with potatoes. May be too salty for some, but overall very good.

Tenderloin should not be cooked in a crock pot.. and I should have known better. The combination of wine, soy sauce and onion soup mix was interesting and made the pork taste sour. Perhaps browning in a skillet before putting in the crock pot would improve the flavor and its appearance. If you do attempt this recipe give yourself a few minutes at the end to make a sauce from the crock pot liquids.

text:
I ended up using a cheaper cut of meat, pork steaks. I braised the steaks in garlic and EVOO and layered the steaks over a large drained, rinsed can of mushrooms. I ended up adding a little brown sugar (felt like it needed SOMETHING) and I only added 1/4 c. of 
water with the red wine. I omitted the soy sauce, as I thought it would make it too salty. I'm glad I did. I also added a can of golden mushroom soup, to thicken it up a little bit. It was good. The bigger kid, my husband and I all ate it but the baby wouldn't touch it.

EDITED TO ADD ONE DAY LATER: I changed my rating. WAY better the next day. The flavor of the wine mellowed a bit and was a nice combination with the rest of the ingredients. I suggest making this the day before, letting it rest overnight, then warming it the next day.

excellent dinner.  Served it with steamed broccoli and little white potatoes.

I used a crock pot liner so when the pork was "done" (see next paragraph)I picked up the liner and dumped the sauce into a pan that I had a roux going in and made the best pork gravy ever.

I don't know about 4 hours on low.  I had a tenderloin that was under 2lbs and it was cooked rare after 3 hours on high and one hour on low.  I will definitely cook this alot longer next time.  

I was really expecting this to be shredded when it was done, but it wasn't.  

Will definitely make it again, and will futz around with the cooking seasonings.  Maybe some ginger and orange juice?

This couldn't be any easier to put together, took all of 5 minutes the night before!  I put the crockpot insert in the fridge overnight which I think allowed the flavors of the sauce to permeate the meat and infuse it with a more intense flavor.  I followed the recipe exactly as written except that it cooked longer than the recipe stated.  The meat was very tender and we were able to break it up with a fork; no knife needed.  I served with homemade mashed potatoes and corn with the gravy on the side which we poured over the potatoes and meat.  My husband and son both thought it was very tasty.  I will be making this again when Pork Tenderloins go on sale at the grocery store.  Nice, easy, hot comforting food for a cold winter's night!  Thanks for an easy, tasty pork recipe!

This recipe really is amazing as the name says. I don't have a crock pot, so I cooked it in the oven, with some minor changes to the recipe. As someone else suggested, I used more garlic than called for, and cut slits in the meat, and pushed the garlic inside. I also cut up some red potatoes and put them in the pot. I just used a large pot with a lid, and cooked it for 2 hours at 250°F, then for another 70 minutes at 300°F, and it came out perfect.

text:
So easy. And so delicious!  Wow.  I was leery after reading the mixed bag of reviews, but I'm very glad I prepared this recipe anyway.  Salty?  Well, admittedly, that's a matter of personal preference, but I stopped using table salt years ago and I'm extra sensitive about too much salt--and I thought the saltiness factor was just fine.  I poked a few holes in the tenderloin, which helped the juice penetrate the meat.  I prepared a 2 1/2 pound loin on low (as the recipe suggests) and it was done in three, not four hours.  Crockpot recipes always seem to get done far faster in my crockpot than the recipe calls for.  We had this for LUNCH--HA! I didn't bother with real potatoes--just instant with the meat and au jus.  It was a feast fit for a king.  My picky eating son rated this 8.2 (you would have to know him) on a scale of 1 to 10--a most high compliment!  I may thicken the sauce with corn starch the next time I make this, but it was terrific "as is."

This? This recipe turned out FANTASTIC. The first time I used a pork tenderloin, and just doubled the amounts of everything to make sure there was enough (we were expecting guests).  The trick, I found, to making sure all the pork was tender was to chop it up into half-fist sized chunks.  Due to oversight, a couple of ingredients were different - half of the red wine was Sangria, and half of the soy sauce was actually teriyaki sauce. 

The second time, I used a pork shoulder roast, carving off chunks of the meat and then just dropping the whole bone into the sauce to cook for the full time.  Everything came out tender and moist and delicious all over.  It was really easy to remove the meat left on the bone from it with just a fork, it was so tender.

I had a couple of 2lb tenderloins, so doubled the recipe, and added my own quirks.  Rubbed the tenderloins with my favorite rub, and seared them briefly in a cast iron skillet to get a nice dark crust started, then put them on top of a bed of onions and mushrooms, added the soup mix, subbed vegetable broth for the water, and added a sliced jalapeno and sweet red pepper.  Added the red wine and garlic.  Smelled heavenly while cooking, and delivered wonderful flavor.  Served with fried rice and the cooking liquids on the side.  It was a hit with my guests, who were both more seasoned cooks than I.

text:
I disagree with some of the reviews.  If you are a cook,  you can look at the ingredients and tell if the sodium level is going to be high. Also, if you use a cooking wine, cut out all other salt, as they are heavy in sodium, as another reviewer mentioned.  So, rather than trash the recipe, adapt for what you think will be too much.  I did use a 2.47 pound pork tenderloin from my local grocery, which is wrapped in a plastic wrapper, not a high end pork tenderloin from our local butcher.  They were B1G1, so it was too good a deal to pass up.  I followed the recipe, but adapted.  No one in our house has a sodium problem, but I don't like excess sodium, so I used a lower sodium version of the onion soup mix, used reduced sodium soy sauce, and drizzled a very small amount (maybe 1-2 tsp) of hickory syrup and maple syrup on top of the meat before cooking.  Since my crockpot has 4 and 6 for high and 8 and 10 for low, I turned it to high for 4 hours.  After that, I turned it to warm until it was time to eat.  My daughter was home when it finished and she did not know what we were doing with it so she shredded it for sandwiches.  It was a delicious mistake!  Next time, I will leave it whole and cut into slices and serve with potatoes and a green vegetable.  This time it was served with brioche buns, sliced onion and slices of cheese.  I will tweak the recipe a little each time, to come up with new flavor combinations we like.  I can see this with sage, thyme and rosemary in the late

text:
My Whole family LOVES this recipe!!! My children can’t get enough of it. ( My children are picky eaters too!) My husband loves it soo much, I have to make 4 lbs of pork (double the recipe). Only thing I do differently is double the water ( 2 cups instead of 1 cup). That way it is super moist. If you have leftovers I take the extra cooked juice from the crockpot to the Rubbermaid container. That way when you reheat the leftovers, the tenderloin isn’t dried out. I also prepare the dish the night before, 10 min prep time if that. Next morning take it out of the  refrigerator, put the crockpot on low and move on with your day until dinner time. Perfect meal for a working family that wants a good filling dinner without the hassle. If you are still on the fence about making this meal, go ahead and make it!!!! You won’t be disappointed. **** Side note, if you add 2 cups of baby carrots to the recipe, they come out amazing too. ****

text:
After reading a few reviews, I made some adjustments. I made a pork rub that consisted of salt, pepper, onion powder, and garlic powder and then seared the pork before putting it into the crock pot. Since I did not use the onion soup mix, I added 1/4 cup water and 3/4 cup red wine (Merlot because that is what I had open), 3 bay leaves, half an onion sliced, and low sodium soy sauce (amount adjusted since I used less liquid). I cooked it in the crock pot on high for 2 hours then turned it down to low for another 2 hours (I think it would have been fine on low for 4 hours).

text:
I made this today- what an easy recipe that is perfect for a lazy, rainy Sunday! I took others’ suggestions and used a 3 lb. pork roast instead of a tenderloin, which is a great cut for the grill but wasted on a slow cooker. I also used low sodium soy sauce and my red wine was Cabernet Sauvignon. I cooked it for 6 hours on low. It was wonderfully tender and I lifted it from the crock in one piece using a spatula. I sliced it and it fell apart, so I could’ve easily shredded it instead. I had enough juice to make some gravy and kept some for au jus, since my husband isn’t a gravy lover. Even my fussy boys loved it! I served it with mashed potatoes and green beans. I recommend this for an easy slow cooker meal (and the leftovers are going to make tasty sandwiches.)

text:
This was easy and delicious.  I would cut the soy a bit maybe by 1-2 teaspoons because the gravy seemed a bit salty for our taste.  I needed to make a double recipe, since my slow cooker is larger and the liquid and meat from one recipe didn't reach the minimum line.  Cooking two tenderloins/double recipe was easy, and since the two of us only eat one half of a t'loin in a sitting, I cut the second t'loin in half, put each of the three pork halves in a Ball pint (wide-mouth) freezer jar, covered all to the top with the juice (there was plenty left), and we have 3 frozen meals ready to go.  Only need to make a pilaf and veggie to complete each meal.  Using Ball freezer canning jars is the perfect way to freeze up soups, too!  Buy Ball's plastic screw caps for the jars.

text:
Gluten free version just as amazing!  I sprinkled sea salt, garlic salt, onion powder and pepper on 2 pork loins then browned them  on the stove (I can't find gluten free onion soup mix).  I used the red wine (a mini merlot that comes in a 4 pack which are great for cooking) to deglaze the pan, and added the soy sauce and a 1/2 cup of water to slow cooker.  I also added 3/4 can of gluten free cream of mushroom soup (found at Whole Foods) and a chopped onion.  Cooked on 325 for about 2 hours then lowered to 250 for a couple of hours.  Added a little cornstarch mixed with water to make gravy at the end.  Yum!!!

text:
I made a 4 1/2 pound pork loin roast.  I doubled the  liquid and seasonings.  I did not change any of the ingredients. I used Black Box Merlot for the wine.  I believe there is a typo about cooking time. When you cook on low heat it is almost always going to be 8 hours.  High heat is 4 hours. I strained the liquid and put it in a pan and added some water with cornstarch dissolved to make a gravy.  The gravy made the roast and my potatoes delicious.  I am not a real fan of just the meat without the gravy. It was very garlicky without the gravy.  My husband said make it again! Typically his comments are "It's not bad."  So him saying that is something.  I highly recommend making gravy with the juice. Make sure to strain the liquid though.  The liquid is pretty salty so don't add any.  I even used low sodium soy sauce.  The majority of all that salt is coming from the onion soup packets.  Being salty it was still very good and I hate over salted foods.

text:
We made this as a family tonight. We love to find easy recipes to use as we are trying to teach our 9 year old and 7 year old how to cook simple meals. We followed the recipe for the most part.

We aren't wine users so we substituted it for Red Grape Juice.

We double the recipe

For the garlic we made a garlic paste so it would stick on top of the loin. We took the called for amount of minced garlic and heated it for 3-4 minutes on high until nice and soft. took the same number of tablespoons of mustard and added the garlic to it and then added a romano and herb cheese seasoning (to taste) to the garlic and mustard and made a paste out of it. Once good and soft we spooned it on the meat and let it it cook the full 4 hours.

My kids who are typically picky eaters loved the meat and we served it along side mashed potatoes. 

I'd say we have a "winner winner, chicken dinner."

I have found that there is no need to purchase onion soup mix since it's mostly dried onions and salt some Worchester...and also contains MSG. I just use dried onions and a few dashes of Worchester, and favorite herbs.  You can save money and have a healthier version of the same flavors.

This is a 5 ?? without question. I followed this recipe exactly as written.  I did brown the meat first but this is totally unnecessary. The flavor was great and it was not too salty for us. text:
As written, we did not care for this recipe. I hate it when people review the recipe as 5-stars, then make all sorts of changes from the way it is written. The second time we made this, we considered all of the 5-star ratings and their changes to - reduce the amount of salt in the recipe by using low-sodium soy sauce, and dehydrated onions and broth instead of dry soup mix. Reduced the overall amount of garlic from 3 tablespoons (Good lord, my intestines!!) to a short shake of garlic powder (we can't tolerate garlic, but we love the flavor). Use a nice drinking red wine, not cooking red - if you wouldn't drink it, why cook with it? After the changes, the new version fit our tastes much better than the original recipe. The advantage of this recipe is that you don't have to brown/sear the tenderloins to start off. This might be a sacrilegious act for the tenderloin people, but it's a whole lot easier when you are very busy and need something that's easy to get going for the family. As noted by some reviewers, we changed the heat setting to HIGH for 3 - 4 hours for two, thawed tenderloins.

I did not make this according to the recipe. The recipe was delicious with the revisions and was easy to prepare. I will definitely make it again. I think next time I'll add carrots and potatoes to make it a complete meal.

Wow!  This recipe is a keeper.  So easy, filled with flavor and low in calories too!  I made it with a 1.3 pound tenderloin but kept the rest of the ingredients the same and ended up throwing away a lot of wonderful sauce/gravy.  I did end up adding some flour to it to thicken it up.
