text:
I have made several recipes from this site but this is only the second I've left a review on. I was so disappointed with the results on this recipe. The flavors and smells are abrasive. The flavors here just don't mesh well and the result is a pungent and salty sauce on top of a texturally strange piece of meat. 

First off, I used a 2.40 lb pork loin roast instead of tenderloin. Secondly, I added two EXTRA cups of water since I was afraid it would be too salty per other reviews. The meat was at 170 degrees after only 3 hours of cooking on low. It was very tender meat, that's the only thing the recipe had going for it. However, it had a weird rubbery texture to it. I think searing it beforehand would help with that. The sauce was just like salty wine with onion chunks. I threw half of it in a pan to make a gravy out of it since it was so brothy and dull. It didn't help much. 

I would not make this again but if I were to, I'd suggest replacing the onion soup mix with a handful of spices (thyme, rosemary, sage, dried or fresh onion, etc), adding beef broth, and using half the wine with no soy sauce, or using the soy sauce with no wine (I  don't think the soy sauce with wine is a good combination at all). Maybe throw some vinegar and a hint of brown sugar in.

I don't add pepper ever, as Mrs. Dash has some in it.  The Mrs. Dash I use is the Original blend, or the onion one with the purple top.  My family is full of picky eaters, and this recipe is a big hit.  Also, I nix the soy sauce.  The onion soup mix has so much salt, it isn't needed.

I put this in my slow cooker this am before I left for work at 7:30 am and we didn't eat dinner until 7:30 pm.  I made some changes because of other reviews  - I used a whole onion instead of onion soup mix and next time I would use only half.  I did the rest just as the recipe said, and it turned out to be the most remarkable pulled pork - fork tender and great flavour.  I added 2 tbsps corn starch mixed with water and poured the sauce into a pot, so I could bring it to a boil and thicken nicely.  The gravy was amazing.  My husband is not aj big fan of pork tenderloin and this he liked this a lot!

text:
My BF and I cooked this for Sunday dinner and were thrilled with the result!  We used a 1.5lb roast from Walmart that had an onion and garlic marinade already and I think it really added an extra element of flavor.  The wine we used was a Marsala (just what we had), low sodium soy, and used enough garlic to put a decent layer on the top of the roast, probably more than the 3 tablespoons called for.  We followed some of the other reviewer's advice and put a few fork holes in it prior to, and about an hour before it was done cooking and periodically basted it.  When it was finished, I added 2 teaspoons of cornstarch to the remaining liquid and made an awesome gravy.  It was a touch salty, but we chose not to add salt to the mashed potatoes and it balanced out beautifully.   Great meal that I will be adding to our repertoire!

text:
This is a nice recipe but I made some changes in it. Too the next time I use this for pork I'll use something besides tenderloin. It was really tasty but a bit dry and this would be better suited to something like a regular pork roast. I changed out the dry onion soup mix for a beef and onion dry soup mix and dropped the soy sauce altogether. Cut back on the garlic to one small section not 2 tblspns and the wine I used was Due Mari 2008 Primitivo which made the best tasting au jus and everyone couldn't stop dipping and pouring more on their plates - it was a hit. I may make the au jus by itself it's so good. That and some garlic bread would be a fine meal. However this was good just could be improved on with a different cut of meat I think.

I was worried that it would be way too soupy but then I ended up getting sidetracked in the evening and totally forgetting about the roast.  So when I got home late that night, I put the entire thing in the fridge.  It smelled really strong (spicy) so I didn't have high hopes for it.  Today I took it out of the crockpot and set it on the cutting board to prepare it for lunchboxes tomorrow.  I stuck the fork in and attempted to cut it in half...it crumbled.  So then I could resist and I quickly boiled up some red potatoes. I will definitely use this and share this with others!

Okay, I'm trying to find the appeal here . . . I followed the recipe exactly. Found the tenderloin to be dry (I use an oval crock pot . . . perhaps it cooks more rapidly than the found ones?). Used a good merlot as my red wine. As another reviewer suggested, I tried to thicken the sauce by adding in some cornstarch/water and turning up to high for 10 minutes, but that did not work at all. I just did not find the tenderloin to be that flavorful. I would not make this again; tenderloin is too expensive to turn out so bland. UPDATE November 2013: it was better this time; used 2 1/2 pounds tenderloin, 2 pkgs soup mix, 1 1/2 times water and wine, and double amount of garlic. Layered chopped red potatoes into bottom; pork on top. Much more tender, not as dry, and flavor was "okay." Still not a terribly impressive recipe, but for the ease of preparation, I'll make again.

In my opinion while gravy is a nice compliment to the dish, gravy only masks the problem (the real challenge is keeping the meat moist).    The next time I make this I will heed the advice of others and sear the meat (hoping that will help keep the meat moist). A very good and easy receipe.  I used a fruit based wine and it gave it a different twist.  I think the big key to this, as all other "slow cooker" meats is to not over cook.  Check your temp on the meat.  Just because you cook it for 10 hours doesn't mean it will be good.  It reaches a point that the flavor and tenderness is cooked out.  I'll sure use this one again.

text:
I made this recipe as posted with no modifications and cooked it for a little over four hours on low. I used low sodium onion soup mix and low sodium soy sauce so it didn't have the overly salty taste others complained of. The flavor we mostly got was from the red wine and garlic. After cooking for about 4.5 hours it was dry and coming apart a little bit--not how tenderloin should be--so I would recommend not cooking it longer than 4 hours, if that. Also, I couldn't get my sauce to thicken even after adding quite a bit of cornstarch, so it was more like an au jus than a gravy. Served with white rice and roasted carrots, it was a pretty good meal, satisfying, but I probably won't prepare pork tenderloin this way again. As others have said, the crockpot does wonders on tough cuts of meat--tender cuts that you pay for are better pan roasted, in the oven, or on the grill.

I did not put the tenderloin in the crockpot.  I planted the minced garlic into the tenderloin and placed sliced onion rings on the top of it.   I put the wine (shiraz), 1 c. beef boullion, 1 Tbs of soy sauce and 1 Tbs Worchestire. I cooked it @ 425 for 45 min, in tented foil, basted it with the sauce, left the foil off for the last 15 min.  Basted it again.  Poured the juices & drippings into a saucepan, added a TBS cornstarch to thicken it.  The tenderloin was great but we pitched the gravy.  TOO salty.  I should have cut the boullion in half.  Smelled great. Hubby loved the meat not the sauce.

OK so it's still in the crock on warm, waiting for DH to get home but I had to review---the roast is moist, not overpowering of garlic or salt I might add. I don't think the wine did anything to it, altho I eyeballed the ingredients and may have been a bit shy on the wine...I'm definitely liking that it is moist, but given the fact that I cooked my 6+ lb tenderloin on low in an AllClad 7 qt slow cooker for almost 9 hours on Lo, it should be moist!!!! :) I used 4 small onions in the bottom, quartered, and about 4-5 pounds small red potatoes in the crock, potatoes were a tad overdone tho.. :(  I think I might make it again and play with the ingredients. Update: I had DH try it and he said it was excellent! The jus is actually very good on the meat, I didn't make a gravy, as he doesn't like gravy. I made this and Sauteed Garlic Asparagus with Karen's suggestion to add the balsamic vinegar and use olive oil - very good!!!

This recipe is ok, but not my favorite for cooking pork tenderloin. After eating, my boyfriend said he prefers when I cook the tenderloin in a roasting bag in the oven. I had to add alot of spices and flavors to get it just right. (and ALOT of garlic!)Also, dont try to make a gravy out of the jucies. I tried to add some cornstarch to the liquid, bring to a boil, and make a gravy. Didnt work! Ended up with a great tasting, but otherwise lumpy and corn-startchy gravy. Overall, im not making a pork loin in the slow-cooker, the oven variation works better for us because its more tender, and has more flavor! Thanks though for bringing a new idea into the kitchen.

GREAT recipe!  Mine came out a bit salty too, but I think it's because I had to substitute seasonings for the onion dip package because I forgot to buy at the store.  I cooked the tenderloin for 8 hours on low (consistently flipping and basting) and it came out so tender. I think I may have added a bit too much of this...leading to the extra salt.  I also did half soy sauce, half Bragg.

Exactly like most other people said with this recipe, it's pretty much the best meat I've ever prepared. My fiance went crazy for it and wants it again -- which is rare with his picky tastes. I followed the advice of many other reviewers and instead of using 3 tbsp of soy sauce, I used only 1 1/2 tbsp soy with 1 1/2 tbsp of Worcheshire. For the wine I used a Beaujolais we had left from our trip to France. The pork came out beautifully. It was so tender you could cut it with a fork. I used the juices to make a gravy and of course made mashed potatoes to go with it. It is an easy meal to make, and definitely a keeper.
